reviews.advice:
For Heaven sake - listen to what your employees have to say
Dont be busy in finding new opportunites for yourself.
reviews.cons:
The company is closed to take any feedback about how to improve.
The management is directive - my way or the highway.
The HR does not want to take any feedback or help.
The company does not want to take steps to get better and this will one day cause a downfall.
reviews.pros:
The company offers wide range of technologies to learn.
The learning opportunities are many and one can grow his/her career by learning new things
reviews.summary: Good Company to Learn , Bad company to stay for long.

reviews.cons: As with any organisation with a strong culture, be honest with yourself about whether you'll be a good fit before deciding to work there. If you need structure and consistency to be happy at work, it might not be the place for you.
reviews.pros: Fantastic, positive and dynamic culture. Always changing, never boring. Lots of opportunity for flexible, driven and collaborative people to achieve rapid advancement if you demonstrate results.

reviews.advice:
Incompetence and vindictiveness look very similar and you will lose your best teachers over and over again, not the ones with the highest 'ratings' but the teachers who can actually teach, if you don't change the atmosphere and attitude of the school. 

I have seen fantastic teachers leave and people who needed help not given that help and instead left to suffer. Your actions have affected people's lives and the teachers at EF Oxford want to work hard and teach students not be used and then thrown away. The management need to take a long look at themselves and think about the damage they have done to good teachers.

 We all worked hard for the year and helped turn the school around and the thanks we got was shameful, competent managers must be appointed.

Don't just appoint yes men.
reviews.cons:
Appalling working conditions

40hrs a week, often with a double banking 30 hr contact time 'summer' timetable even in winter. Many teachers stay until 7pm even 9pm (unpaid) to plan and many come in on weekends. The management are out the door at 5.30 sharp. There is a mentality of don't bother planning, which affects class quality and teacher burnout.

Understaffed and overworked, leading to teacher breakdowns in the staff room, I've lost count of how many teachers I have seen in tears due to stress and being pushed too hard. It is a very upsetting environment to be part of and at times can become violent, one teacher recently snapped and shouted and swore in the corridor and threw things in the staff room.   

Toxic environment of us vs them mentality with the management. The management are sorely under trained and lack basic man management skills. They allow anonymous, informal complaints with no evidence, to escalate into close door meetings where you are intimidated and questioned on every aspect of what you do. Such accusations can be- 'Negativity', 'undermining teachers abilities' or 'making teachers feel uncomfortable'. All with no evidence and all very stressful. Most of the complaints come from senior teachers who listen in on private conversations and report back to the management or simply make things up. It is impossible to defend yourself when you don't even know/understand what you said or did. This behaviour led to several teachers leaving and is wholly unacceptable, bordering on bullying. 

Further to this, the inductions are atrocious and almost non existent. The support is apparently available only if you go and ask for it and only when the office door is literally open which it is often not, leaving many teachers to make crucial decisions themselves.  A teacher with little experience who recently started was fired instead of given support as his classes weren't up to standard and absolutely no one helped him. 

Chances of promotion appear to be based on how friendly you are with the management. Often candidates with a DELTA or more experience are overlooked for teachers who may have been there longer. A teacher who was on very good terms with the management quickly become a senior teacher (within 6 months), overlooking a candidate who had actually been there longer and got on well with other teachers leading many, whether true or not, to believe that the system is based on cronyism. 
 
Inappropriate messaging between teachers and students. Several teachers were privately messaging students on social media as well as clubbing and drinking with them. Most of them have now left.

Poor quality classrooms and materials- 17 students in a class, some of the classrooms are tiny with barely enough space for 17 students and a teacher, in the summer the temperatures can reach unbearable and unsafe levels, causing students and teachers to feel sick. Only some have projectors and slow computers, a big disappointment for a 'flagship' school, many broken chairs or chairs with small flip tables despite students preferring rooms with tables. The EF books themselves are of the poorest quality: full of mistakes, awful audio recordings and answers to reading and listening that don't even make sense, they are often ditched for better books. Constantly breaking photocopiers. Students are paying  a lot and receiving very little quality in return.

All round unfriendly colleagues, outside of the staff room, with poor, unpaid, interns working ridiculously hard to try and keep students happy.   

A broken review system where a teacher is expected to get 4.4/5 on their student evaluations or expect to be fired and/or subjected to constant private meetings. The review system only determines whether or not the student likes you which is almost impossible to improve with  many teachers becoming close friends with students or simply playing games with them in order to achieve a high rating. One teacher who received low ratings was hounded out of the school and spent her final week off due to stress and anxiety induced by the job.  

Any success or target achieved is met with sweets or ice cream as if we are children. This is a huge business with a massive turnover and there is nothing in the budget for bonuses for reaching targets or even to buy books. The salary is also too low, 18k a year is not enough to live in Oxford, one of the most expensive places in England. Many teachers share houses with people and still pay upwards of £500. 

Insanely high turnover, we lost 4 teachers in a week once, and in my one year there I saw possibly 20+ people come and go.  Many sighting the working conditions and management as reasons for leaving

jobTitle.text: English As A Second Language Teacher

reviews.pros:
Fellow teachers- Some of the strongest people I've met. Sadly, no one who started with me in January 2018 remains there on a full-time contract.

Students- You get some great students who can really make the difference between a good day and a bad day.
reviews.summary: The worst school I have ever worked at. EF Oxford

reviews.cons:
- Very low salary for the amount and quality of work you're expected to do. 
- I found it really hard to advance my career or get a raise even after getting good feedback on performance reviews (lots of evasion from management when the topic got brought up)
reviews.pros:
- Supportive and talented team.
- Fun place to work and positive environment.
- Good work life/balance.
- Overall good place to start a career.

reviews.advice:
Instead of investing in a bike team, uber-expensive coffee machines and fancy furniture, invest in your people. Otherwise you will be left with the bored and desperate people who will stay with you on a sinking ship.

Pay your employees development courses and do not make it so difficult to use the allowance of 1,500USD yearly. Create a platform of knowledge that is properly structured by a team dedicated to that rather than have one person here and one person there do it for free.

Pay proper base salaries and stop exploiting people. Beautiful words mean nothing when they are empty which they were and we all felt it. Today's generations feel the difference and need more benefits than a free gym, coffee, etc. Make home-office possible for all employees every day of the week and stop questioning people's integrity. Integrity does not arise when you demand for it. It comes from trust.
reviews.cons:
The low budgets given to the various products of EF are also represented in the low budgets for staff and development. Managers during my time at EF have changed half a dozen times; it took long for senior management to hire one level above me and even on my level due to low attraction value of positions and compensation/base salary. 
Most staff start out as trainee with 2,000 monthly gross salary which hardly anyone can survive on in Zurich. The reason people accept this low salary is that they are expats and often desperate. 
Once you are inside the organisation which is highly political and - at least the EF Educational Tours department - moving slow in terms of changes, you realise that senior management, i.e. CEO does not value its staff and tries to keep the employees 'engaged' through sparse want-to-be motivational E-Mails, free-booze parties and other cheap and outdated goodies. 
Development and staff training is handled on a department basis and often initiated and carried out by employees that are invested. When they realise the work-load for their actual job is immensely high (I did the work that should have been divided amongst 3 employees) they loose motivation and the respect of their managers for not-so-good managers are common at EF depending on the department and product. They sometimes cannot be blamed for not supporting you because of the lack of support they receive from higher above. 

Money is everything for EF and the Hult family and the longer you work at EF the more you realise that their mission to open the eyes through education and a fair world does not reach and is acted out in the office amongst employees. Base salaries are ridiculously low so that I could have worked at the till at Migros without the stress and exploitation. 

Progressing your career is many times not possible due to managers hiring from outside. Once you have hit the ceiling you either look sideways and for opportunities inside the company or leave. The latter is likely to be the better option.
reviews.pros:
Very nice atmosphere and colleagues who mostly are invested and like what they do. Office events that are appealing to the young staff base whose average age is around 25. For the not so young employees of EF the office parties with chips and free booze from the cheapest supermarket are not so appealing. 
- Free gym / gym classes
- Free tea/coffee
- Big cafeteria to warm up meals
- Rooftop terrace and modern office
- Rest room /games room

The one star is really for the atmosphere wholly created by the junior employees. Without them and their power and ideas EF would not be much.

reviews.cons: - If a student doesn’t turn up, you only get paid for 15 mins of waiting. I would argue that you should still receive your full salary as the company has still received the students payment.

employerResponses.response:
Thank you so much for sharing your experience in a review! We are always grateful to receive feedback from teachers, and we are happy to hear about your positive experience with your students and lessons. 

When a student does not enter the lesson before 15 minutes, then the lesson is considered a Student No-Show. Parents and guardians are aware that students must arrive before 15 minutes for the classes to occur. After 15 minutes, teachers can then leave the online classroom and register that the student did not attend. They then receive 80% compensation at their usual rate, as opposed to 100% compensation for teaching a full 25-minute class and submitting an after-class report.

reviews.pros:
- Lessons pre planned 
- Good training for new teachers 
- Good salary given you don’t have to plan any of the 
 classes 
- Really friendly students

reviews.advice: Show a slither of respect to your staff and pay them enough to get by.
reviews.cons: Honestly this company is so bad. They want to hire professionals with specific qualifications but they don't want to pay them properly. I earned more working a minimum wage job full time than I did at this place, and it was extremely demanding. Avoid like the plague.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for sharing with us your review. We are continuing to review our compensation structure to ensure we are offering competitive packages within our sector. We always want to improve, so receiving feedback like yours is helpful in doing so. We wish you the best in your career.

reviews.pros: Extremely fast paced so good if you are mentally unhinged to begin with..

reviews.advice: Value your employees and establish a much better management structure.
reviews.cons:
-Pay is insubstantial to say the very least.  

-They portray an unrealistic work environment.  They will tell you it's fun, young, and exciting.  It is young, however it is neither fun or exciting.  On a social level it is like being back in High School where everyone knows your business and there is more participation in back stabbing in order to get a leg up, rather than working for it.  Also, it's not exciting because you are expected to call through your pipeline like a machine and this becomes brainless very fast.  

-Management  focuses more on numbers than an individuals overall development.  With proper development numbers will follow organically while maintaing a successful and happy work force. 

-Middle Management is sub-par mainly due to the fact that they lack overall experience and ability to assist in professional development. 

-Some Senior Level Managment is underqualified and unprofessional.  Senior Management does not value their employees.  Some of these individuals openly express their feelings of regret for hiring current employees.  Additionally, they talk down in a demeaning manner to new and tenured employees creating an unstable and unhealthy work environment.  At an organizational level, there are many instances where entry level employees to high-ups partake in innapropriate conversations with regards to co-workers and other varying subjects. This may be in part to having a bar located on the first floor of the building.  I guess some people shouldn't consume alcohol if they can't act in an appropriate manner. 

-Very Political.  For the most part, promotion from within is based on who management likes on a personal level and is not based on abilities, growth potential, level of intelligence, and overall tenure and contributions at an organizational level.
reviews.pros: If you are right out of college and lack overall professional experience EF can be a good place to start your career.  They have thorough entry level sales training which provides a good basis and understanding for a career in sales.  If you find you like sales and have excelled, then move on and respectfully take your skills elsewhere.
reviews.summary: Smithsonian Student Travel - Decent FIrst Job, Inadequate Management & Talent Retention

reviews.cons:
* dont get to work on interesting stuffs.
* Highly insecure job
* If u have two options in hand, make it 2nd choice n never 1st  choice.
* can be removed  from the job at any instant of time.(Make up your mind for sudden decision that management makes)
reviews.pros:
friendly environment and friendly managers
Beautiful office

reviews.cons:
- Hike is less, unless you are getting a promotion.
- You need to speak up and advertise yourself for your hard work to be recognized.
- At times, the work load is too much and you end up working late nights and weekends(but you would be pain for working on weekends). 
- No onsite opportunity.
reviews.pros:
- Take home salary is good.
- Friendly and supportive team members.
- Approachable managers.
reviews.summary: Fun and nice place to work
